Title: Security Decisions Are Not Made Based on Client-Accessible Parameters
DirectLink: Security Decisions Are Not Made Based on Client-Accessible Parameters

Data:
Applies to

Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

What to Check For

Ensure your application does not make security decisions based on parameters that are accessible by the client.

Why

Using client-accessible data to make security decisions allows the users to access and modify the data and work around security measures.

How to Check

Use the following steps to ensure that your application does not delegate parts of its security decision mechanism to the client-side:

  1. Verify that there are no security decision points on the client. Review your application's design and requirements. Ensure that no security decisions are made on the client-side. Common areas that might affect your application's security model include:

    • URL-based parameters
    • Form-based parameters
    • Cookies
    • HTTP headers

    Make sure that appropriate server-side security has been enforced.

  2. Verify that user input does not affect security decisions. Trace all user input from source to sink. Verify that user input does not have a direct impact on your application's security decisions. Common mistakes to look out for include:

    • Undocumented parameters that enable privileged functionality
    • Storing user privileges inside cookies

  3. Check if security decisions can be tampered with by the client. Through the use of parameter tampering attacks, ensure that users cannot tamper with your application's security decisions.

How to Fix

Security decisions should not be based on any data over which the client has control. Common mistakes include relying on data inside unprotected cookies, hidden fields or query strings.

To ensure that no security decisions are based on client-accessible data:

  1. Identify security decision points. Carefully examine the points in the code that are related to your application's security model. It is critical that no decision points are placed in the client. Because this is a design issue, it is recommended to use threat modeling to determine and evaluate the security decision points.

  2. Trace data that influences security decisions. Tracing the data that influences security decisions helps determine if the data is vulnerable to any client-based attacks. Make sure that the client cannot modify or influence this data.

  3. Prove that security-related data cannot be tampered with by the client. Use cryptography or your application's design to ensure that security related data cannot be tampered with by the client.

  4. Mark all exceptions to this guideline. Note all exceptions made to this guideline. Thoroughly examine the code associated with such instances. Verify that all instances are provided in the business logic and are intended.
